pros: Excellent public employee benefits. If you are looking to settle in and just secure a retirement pension in a position with no advancement, promotions, fixed 2% annual salary raises, and don't mind vegetating on a 9-5 one hour lunch for 25 years doing exactly the same, this place is perfect for you.
cons: Heavy politics, employee discrimination base on gender, age, and race. This is not a welcome setting environment for smart self driven and educated professionals that are focus on advancing their careers and can provide expertise to advance the institution. They prefer those who can blend in and are whiling to maintain the status quo. What's more, even though this is a Hispanic Serving Institution, as an employee, Hispanics are not promoted.

review_title: Great place to work as a student
pros: The people are accommodating and thoughtful. Get back so much. Intelligent, supportive, and caring supervisors and staff. Friendly and bright coworkers. When not needed to help students in the MSWIN, tutors are typically discussing and learning about STEM-related topics, and solving STEM-related problems or challenges, as well as studying for classes. Staff are accommodating and understanding of tutors' academic priorities and goals. Encourage and provide many opportunities for growth, not just as a tutor, but also academic and personal. Provides many resources for handling challenging tutoring situations. Their goal of encouraging and supporting students to become independent learners is clear and well-thought-out with many resources available for both the students being tutored and the tutors. Pay is better than most of the public (and some of the private) colleges in the state (from what I have heard).
cons: Can encounter challenging/ difficult and unique situations while tutoring. Break room is decent. Occasionally low on dry-erase markers. Sometimes the excuses can get frustrating. Timesheet reporting (especially pre-covid when it was on paper) was a bit frustrating.

pros: The faculty I worked with were really good and smart.

pros: Collegiate environment and cohesive, forward-thinking co-workers. Very friendly and team-spirited on the surface. Excellent and realistic balance between work and life that is almost impossible to find in corporate culture.
cons: Everything has a chain of command but no one seems to know what it is and it changes in midstream, just as you finally figure it out. Learning how to process a mailing took a conversation with four people who were all wrong. More time is wasted dealing with the simplest stuff that there can only be room for improvement.

review_title: Overall good place to work but do not expect advancement
pros: The colleagues are very friendly. Once your chair trusts your instructional ability, he/she usually leaves you to do your  job.
cons: Since the new president (it is no longer Jerry Ryan; this website's info needs to be updated), a lot of cuts have been made, especially in regards to full time contigent faculty. There is no longer any tenure track positions available for the forseeable future. This makes it very difficult to effectively teach students, especially the ones who need extra help outside fo contact time. It also demoralizes the workforce as there is currently no longer paths to advancement at the college.

pros:
*Wonderful staff and faculty
*Students are excellent
*Conveniently located (close to major highways)
*Wonderful President who is focused not only on the success of the school, but also invests in the students by making smart financial decisions
*FANTASTIC adjunct faculty support
cons:
*Lately I haven't seen too many tenure-track opportunities in the sciences and math courses
*Pay scale for non-administrators isn't that competitive

pros: Amazing opportunities to make a difference in the life of a student to show them that the world is not so black and white. I find the strengths in my students and exploit them while minimizing their weaknesses. The theories I teach them are good for not only the subject matter but also for life. My goal is for the students to come into my classes as business beginners and come out as business professionals.
cons: Advancement is an issue in this college.
